title: 112_s3077
content:
The Act is titled the "Pro Football Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act". The Pro Football Hall of Fame's mission is to honor individuals who have made outstanding contributions to professional football, preserve historic documents and artifacts, educate the public about the sport's origin and growth, and promote its positive values. The Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963 with a charter class of 17 players. The Pro Football Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963 with a charter class of 17 players, coaches, and contributors, including legends like Sammy Baugh, Red Grange, and Jim Thorpe. As of 2012, there are 273 members inducted into the Hall of Fame, each represented by a bronze bust. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, established in 1963, has inducted legends such as Sammy Baugh, Red Grange, and Jim Thorpe. There are currently 273 members in the Hall of Fame, each represented by a bronze bust, gold jacket, and ring. The museum has welcomed nearly 9 million visitors since its opening, growing from a 19,000-square-foot building to a 118,000-square-foot facility. The Pro Football Hall of Fame has grown from a 19,000-square-foot building to a 118,000-square-foot facility through expansions in 1971, 1978, 1995, and 2011-2013. It houses the world's largest collection on professional football, with over 20,000 three-dimensional items. The Pro Football Hall of Fame has undergone multiple expansions and exhibit renovations over the years. It houses the world's largest collection on professional football, including over 20,000 three-dimensional artifacts and 20 million pages of documents. The museum reaches a global audience of nearly 15 million people annually. The Pro Football Hall of Fame houses over 20,000 artifacts and 20 million pages of documents, including 3 million photographic images. It reaches a worldwide audience of nearly 15 million people annually through various channels such as the museum, events, website, and educational programs. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, and containing 90% gold and 10% alloy. Additionally, $1 silver coins will be minted weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The $1 silver coins weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The half-dollar clad coins weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and meet specifications for half-dollar coins. The half-dollar clad coins minted under this Act weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and meet specifications for half-dollar coins. They are legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of professional football, with inscriptions including the coin's value, the year 2016, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design for the coins minted under this Act in 2016 will include inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility of the United States Mint during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2016.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. The Secretary will offer bulk sales of coins at a discount and accept prepaid orders before issuance at a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. Surcharges received are promptly paid to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame is subject to audits. The Secretary pays surcharges from coin sales to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame is subject to audits for the amounts received. No surcharge can be included for any coin issuance if the Hall of Fame has already received funds for that calendar year. The Secretary of the Treasury must comply with audit requirements for amounts received under subsection (b) of title 31, United States Code. No surcharge can be included for coin issuance if it would exceed the annual limitation of 2 commemorative coin programs. The Secretary may issue guidance to implement this limitation.
